metadata.titleEn: Selenium contents in the environment and human body in Kashin-Beck Disease endemic areas of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau dataset (2000-2018)
metadata.description: The data set contains the average contents of selenium in soil, drinking water, main grains (highland barley, tsamba, wheat, imported rice, etc.) and human hair in Kashin-Beck Disease endemic areas of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau. The data were mainly collected from all the relevant Chinese and English literatures published from 2000 to 2018, according to the strict literature screening criteria and quality evaluation by experts. Some of the data were collected from self-testing of samples. The monitoring values of different years in the same region (county or district) were integrated by the weighted average of the sample size and the average selenium content of the sample. This data set covers 39 counties affected with Kashin-Beck disease in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, basically covering the main areas of each endemic area. The effective sample sizes were more than 7000. It can reflect the average selenium level in the endemic areas of Qinghai-Tibet Plateau at the present stage, and provide a data basis for the prevention and control of endemic diseases in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau as well as the study of relationships between selenium and other related diseases.
metadata.instructions: File name: data stored in XLSX format, a total of three files, each file name represents the table contains data.The Selenium content in soil and water corresponding to the file called: the Selenium in soil and drinking water. The XLSX, Selenium content in the staple food corresponding: the Selenium in food. The XLSX, Selenium content in human hair: Selenium in human hair. XLSX data method of use: use Excel to open directly.

literatureList.titleEn: Study on the selenium levels in the environment, food, and population in the endemic area of Kashin-Beck disease on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of data collection methods used to determine selenium content in environmental and human samples in regions affected by Kashin-Beck disease on the Tibetan Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: selenium content data from soil, drinking water, major grains, human hair, literature published between 2000 and 2018, strict literature screening standards, expert quality evaluations, self-measured samples, weighted average based on sample size and selenium mean content

Quantification.Question: What is the effective sample size used to reflect the average selenium level in the endemic areas of Kashin-Beck disease on the Tibetan Plateau?

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'weighted average integration' in the context of selenium concentration data collection?
Definition.Answer: Weighted average integration refers to the method of combining selenium concentration data from the same region over different years by using the sample size and the average selenium content of the samples as weights. This approach helps to consolidate data more accurately to reflect the average selenium levels in the specified area, accounting for variations in sample sizes across different studies.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects on environmental and human selenium levels in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau if the data collection methods incorporate a broader range of sample types over an extended period?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Incorporating a broader range of sample types over an extended period could lead to a more comprehensive understanding of selenium distribution and its variations across different environmental media and human populations. It may enhance the accuracy of selenium level assessments in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau and provide deeper insights into the relationship between selenium content and the prevalence of local conditions like Kashin-Beck disease. This could inform the development of more effective public health strategies and environmental management policies.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives behind gathering selenium content data from environmental and human sources in areas affected by Kashin-Beck disease on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives behind gathering selenium content data from environmental and human sources in areas affected by Kashin-Beck disease on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau are to reflect the current average selenium levels in these regions, assist in the prevention and control of endemic diseases, and study the relationship between selenium and other related diseases. The dataset aims to provide a comprehensive view of selenium distribution across soils, water, and staple foods, as well as in human hair, based on data collected from extensive literature and sample testing from 2000 to 2018.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures can be followed to integrate selenium content measurements from soil, water, and food samples across various years and locations in regions affected by bone disease on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The integration of selenium content measurements involves collecting data from soil, drinking water, and major grains such as barley, zanba, wheat, and rice. The data are mainly sourced from all relevant Chinese and English literature published between 2000 and 2018, following strict literature screening standards and expert quality evaluations. Additionally, some data are obtained from self-measured samples. For the same region (county or district) across different years, the selenium content is integrated using a weighted average of sample sizes and the average selenium content of samples.

Expectation.Question: Why might the selenium content in environmental samples from the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau not align with expected levels based on known geological and environmental factors?
Expectation.Answer: The selenium content in environmental samples from the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau is derived from data spanning 2000-2018, which includes samples from soil, drinking water, and major grains. The dataset utilizes a weighted average to integrate selenium levels from various monitoring efforts across different years and regions. This approach, coupled with variability in local environmental conditions and potential gaps in data collection, might lead to discrepancies between measured and expected selenium levels.
